body: Three men were killed in separate shootings in Brooklyn on Sunday night. The police found the bodies of a 44-year-old man and another man, both shot numerous times, in an apartment on Kings Highway in East Flatbush around 6 p.m. Neither man was immediately identified by the police. In Bushwick, a third man, Leslie Prosper, 37, was found fatally
title: 3 Men Are Killed In Brooklyn Gunfire

title: She Aided Victims of Shootings, and She Became One

body: WHEN Robert A. M. Stern was appointed dean of the Yale School of Architecture in 1998, the reaction among a broad swath of students, faculty members and prominent architects was shock mixed with disdainful indignation. Too traditional, they argued, a backward decision for an institution known for producing the progressive architects of tomorrow.
title: ARCHITECTURE; Building Respect At Yale

title: LIVING IN | FLATBUSH, BROOKLYN; Note to City Dwellers: Steals Available Here

title: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; Worshiping Different Gods (But United on the Issue of Pork)

body: THE Brooklyn real estate market has turned into a bundle of contradictions in recent months. title: Brooklyn: A Bargain Hunter's Guide

title: Even in New York, Affordable Apartments

body: There it is, past the weathered men bent over rows of empty beer bottles headed to a recycler at a nickel apiece. It is parked on the sidewalk and shackled with a thick chain to a rusty old fence. title: PROSPECT HEIGHTS JOURNAL; He Caters to a Brooklyn Kind of Carriage Trade

body: The name of the New York Baroque Dance Company's new program is ''Points of Departure.'' But how can an audience tell just what those points are? title: DANCE REVIEW | NEW YORK BAROQUE DANCE COMPANY; Give-and-Take in a Dialogue With the Baroque

body: A brief but fierce storm drenched the New York region just before the morning rush yesterday, paralyzing the transit system, flooding major thoroughfares, cutting off electricity to thousands of homes and causing confusion that lingered through a humid, sweaty day. The storm, which sent water gushing into subway tunnels and swirling over commuter
title: A Sudden Storm Brings A Metropolis to Its Knees

body: ASSUMING the worst, Lesley Horton was extra-prepared when she embarked on her apartment hunt last spring. She calculated how much she could pay in rent -- a maximum of $1,600 a month, depending on the amount of the broker's fee and security deposit. title: THE HUNT; Fully Prepared for Anything

title: SUMMER RITUALS | BLACKTOP BEACH; Dwindling Temples in the Sky for Sun Worshipers

body: FOR CHILDREN THE GUMBALL GANG: CRIME-SOLVING KIDS Bull's-eye. That's the image likely to be lingering in your mind long after seeing this lively comedy from Tada! Youth Theater. body: Lillian Rivera met Officer Russel Timoshenko only once, but it was enough. She was coming out of the subway in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, a few months ago when she saw a handsome young police officer walk by. She stopped him to ask him something that had been on her mind: What is it like to be a police officer? Should she go for it? She is 16 years
title: A Solid Stream of Mourners At a Wake for a Slain Officer

body: The funeral of Officer Russel Timoshenko, who died Saturday, five days after he was shot during a traffic stop in Brooklyn, has been scheduled for 9:30 a.m. Thursday at the I. J. Morris funeral home in Flatbush. The viewing will take place from 4 to 9 p.m. tomorrow and Wednesday at the funeral home, at 1895 Flatbush Avenue. The funeral for Officer
title: Slain Officer's Funeral Set for Thursday

body: GILBERT--Stephen, passed away peacefully on July 12, 2007. Wonderful and beloved husband of Sandra Gilbert for 46 years, adored and cherished father of Holly Gilbert Mayer and Ira Gilbert. Born on January 18, 1932, he was a proud graduate of Columbia University and served as a neurologist in Brooklyn. He was a bright, unique, irreplaceable spirit.
title: Paid Notice: Deaths GILBERT, STEPHEN

title: For Many Guyanese-Americans, Fun Vanishes From a July Sunday

author: E-mail: streetscapes@nytimes.com
body: IT is hard to believe that the little domed fantasy, as fragile as spun sugar, at 111 Clarkson Avenue in Flatbush, Brooklyn, is even standing, let alone still largely intact. Built in 1902 by Herman Raub, a brewer, it may look like a near wreck to passers-by, but inside it has been preserved, even burnished, by its longtime owner, Raphael Berger.
title: STREETSCAPES | FLATBUSH, BROOKLYN; Beyond Decay, a Fantastical Three-Story Concoction

body: NUSSBAUM--Arnold, M.D. The medical staff of Maimonides Medical Center records with deep sorrow the death of Dr. Arnold Nussbaum. Dr. Nussbaum was associated with Maimonides Medical Center in the Department of Pediatrics for over 50 years. He was an outstanding physician and a major teacher to the pediatric residence. He will be sorely missed by all

body: Ever since it was proposed, the Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn has simultaneously been the borough's biggest, most controversial and least understood real estate development. Critics have long suggested that the project is a taxpayer-subsidized bonanza for the developer, the project's promised jobs and subsidized housing a kind of Trojan horse
title: Documents Show Risk In Big Project In Brooklyn

title: Storms Delay L.I.R.R. and Shut Down Power

body: An 18-month-old boy was killed when he was run over by a neighbor's car in a Flatbush driveway yesterday shortly after 5 p.m., the police said. The boy was taken to Kings County Hospital Center, where he was pronounced dead on arrival. The neighbor, who was backing the car out on East 26th Street near Avenue I, was unaware of the accident and drove
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: 18-Month-Old Run Over In Driveway

body: A driver lost control of his livery cab on Flatbush Avenue yesterday afternoon and drove onto the sidewalk, striking two teenage boys and a man, the police said. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Three Struck By Cab On Sidewalk

body: A DENSELY packed 1,200-acre swath of central Brooklyn, Ocean Hill-Brownsville is not among the neighborhoods to have been swept up in the borough's recent renaissance. body: Two days after 13 members of the Haitian national junior soccer team disappeared during a stopover at Kennedy International Airport, all but one had returned voluntarily, a Haitian diplomat said last night. The last boy was being held by the police and was waiting to be picked up, the diplomat said, but did not disclose the location. The diplomat,
title: Haitian Teammates Turn Up After a Detour

body: Mayor Bloomberg's fast-advancing plan to charge drivers $8 to drive in the most congested parts of Manhattan may seem geared mostly toward the suburbanites whom many blame for Manhattan's perpetually snarled weekday traffic. But in fact, most of the drivers who would have to pay the toll are the mayor's own constituents: residents of the city
title: Outside Manhattan, Many Oppose Bloomberg's Traffic Plan

body: IT was 5 in the afternoon, and the scratched-up green Dodge pickup was stopped at a light at Foster and Remsen Avenues in Canarsie, Brooklyn. A teetering bureau and a load of wooden slats were in back. ''Look at that,'' said Lt. Robert DeRossi, a barrel-chested, baby-faced officer who was at the wheel of an unmarked white Jeep. His partner, Officer
title: Target: TRASH

body: The traffic light at Fifth and Flatbush Avenues in Brooklyn changed. Thomas Carlton, a traffic enforcement agent, went into action, herding three stragglers -- cars driven by people oblivious to the idea that an intersection is not the place to be during a red light. ''Sometimes you've got to be the light yourself,'' Mr. Carlton said yesterday,
title: Traffic Agents Talk About the Prospect of New Ticket-Writing Powers

title: Paid Notice: Deaths SCHWARTZ, HELEN (NEE CLIMO)

body: GERSCHWER--Honorable Seymour, known as Sy, died peacefully at his home in Brooklyn on May 2, 2007. He was 82. A graduate of Brooklyn College and St. John's University School of Law, he was elected as a Civil Court Judge in 1984 and served as a Criminal Court Judge and Acting Supreme Court Justice in Brooklyn for the entirety of his ten-year term.
title: Paid Notice: Deaths GERSCHWER, HONORABLE SEYMOUR, KNOWN AS SY

author: E-mail: homefront@nytimes.com.
body: WANGLA LAMA, 37, of Queens, has long supported himself by working in restaurant kitchens. In his native Nepal, when he was not employed as a mountain guide, he made his living as a cook. For most of his nine years in the United States, he worked in a Japanese restaurant in Manhattan, he said, rising from busboy to cook, until it closed in February.
title: OFFICE SPACE: HOME FRONT; At Whole Foods, a Welcome Sign For Immigrants Seeking Jobs

body: THE musician in the painting ''The Bass Player'' has long, languid arms wrapped around his instrument, his eyes half-closed. He seems lost in his own world. So at times does the portrait's artist, Justin Bua, whose characters are from a world far away in place and time: the pregentrified streets of the Upper West Side of Manhattan in the 1970s and
title: ART; A Lost New York as Seen From Way Out West

title: SPARE TIMES: April 27 - May 3; For Children

body: The 2007 season of show houses and house and garden tours runs through fall, with several events every weekend. Visitors -- dreamers, planners, would-be master builders and just plain oglers -- can peer into rooms that have been painstakingly restored to period detail, fancifully concocted with the latest whimsy and stuffed with owners' collections

body: Collectively, patches worn by New York City firefighters form a quilt, a tapestry intertwining the history of the city and that of the Fire Department, an institution with century-old standing in some of the city's oldest neighborhoods, the affluent and the afflicted alike. There are the Harlem Hose Trotters of Engine 36. And Engine 55 in Little
title: To Many in the Department, A Link to a Proud Tradition

title: LIVING IN/Downtown Brooklyn; Now Open for Living, as Well as Business

title: A Road Not Taken, Much

title: Rats in His Sights, and in His Backpack, Too

body: A 27-year-old police officer was shot in the leg while trying to arrest a man who was smoking marijuana on a Brooklyn street last night, according to the authorities. title: Making Arrest, Officer Is Shot In Lower Leg

title: FOOD STUFF; OFF THE MENU

title: STREETSCAPES/Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn; The Kings Is Dead! Long Live the Kings!

body: I LIVE in Vladimir V. Putin's hometown, not far from the palaces of the czars, but on a windowsill in my apartment, I have a phone that lives in Brooklyn. It makes and receives calls on the borough's area code as surely as a phone in a takeout joint on Flatbush Avenue, never letting on that it is 4,500 miles away from its supposed stomping ground.
title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Seven One Eight; To Reach Me in Russia, Just Dial Brooklyn

body: The apartment was destroyed. Blackened boards jutted from the walls like bared bone. Wet ashes half an inch deep pooled in the hallway. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: KENSINGTON; Calling the Faithful And Getting Complaints

title: Man With Fake Machine Gun Arrested

Tomorrow at 3 p.m., ''Popping, Locking, Uprocking and Breaking: Roots of Hip-Hop Dance,'' a lecture and demonstration by Jorge (PopMaster Fabel) Pabon and others. Sunday at 3 p.m., ''Robert Caro: Reflections on Robert
title: SPARE TIMES: Feb. 9 - Feb. 15

body: An investment group agreed at 3 a.m. yesterday to buy Starrett City, the sprawling low- and moderate-income apartment complex on Jamaica Bay in Brooklyn, for $1.3 billion, a price that experts say illustrates an exuberant real estate market. The sale already promises to turn into a flashpoint in the escalating battle over affordable housing for
title: $1.3 Billion Buys Giant Brooklyn Complex

body: Maria Williams and her brood of eight eat dinner together, traverse the country together and watch movies together. They excel at math, music and sibling rivalry. But their most remarkable talent, the one that truly sets them apart, is playing the dozens; quips find their targets with the speed and precision of a surgical air assault. Tashawna
title: The Neediest Cases; A Home Short on Cash but Overflowing With Love and Laughter

title: The Listings: Feb. 2 - Feb. 8

body: Around Town Museums and Sites MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE, 36-01 35th Avenue, Astoria, Queens. Tonight at 7:30, a screening of ''Punching at the Sun,'' a 2006 film set in Queens and written and directed by Tanuj Chopra, a graduate student at Columbia, who will discuss the film afterward. Through April 15, ''Star Trek: 40 Years of Fandom,'' an
title: SPARE TIMES: Feb. 2 - Feb. 8

author: E-mail: haberman@nytimes.com
body: From Michael Harris's house in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, it is a seven-block walk to the nearest subway station. Let's be more precise. It would be a seven-block walk if Mr. Harris could in fact walk it. But dystonia, a neurological disorder that he has endured since childhood, forces him to use a motorized wheelchair. And the station, Avenue U on
title: NYC; Daunted by the Subway? Try It in a Wheelchair

body: Carlos Lezama, who as president of the West Indian American Day Carnival Association transformed a Brooklyn block party into the city's largest parade, with millions of spectators lining two miles of Eastern Parkway each Labor Day to enjoy throbbing steel-pan bands, ostrich-plumed dancers and fantastical floats, died on Monday. He was 83. His
title: Carlos Lezama, 83, Dies; Shaped West Indian Parade

body: ROB JETT, a 51-year-old Brooklyn birdwatcher who maintains a blog called Citybirder, has long been fascinated by the red-tailed hawks living in Prospect Park. On a bright, crisp day in February 2002, he set out for the park's Third Street playground to investigate a tip that one had been seen in the area. As it turned out, his task was easier than
title: NEW YORK OBSERVED; Love, and Death, Is in the Air

body: FOR a time after Mona Thong and her husband, Robert Stamicar, moved to Brooklyn from Toronto in 2004, they lived on Montgomery Place in Park Slope, perhaps the most sought-after location in the neighborhood, if not all of Brooklyn. The street is an immaculate ensemble of bay windows, elegantly angled rooftops, understated columns and brownstone
title: LIVING IN/Park Slope, Brooklyn; Coveted, Whether Stone-Clad or Bare Brick

body: Ruth Davis can be shy with new visitors, a quiet presence behind the counter of this no-frills storefront deli in a residential section of White Plains just west of the County Center. But the Jamaican tastes she serves up are bold, authentic and well worth ferreting out. Her beef and chicken patties ($1.50 each), with their flaky crusts and
title: QUICK BITE/White Plains; Authentic Taste Of Jamaica In a Deli Without Frills

body: Forest City Ratner Companies, the developer of the planned $4 billion Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn, has insisted during the long public debate over the project that it will do anything to ensure that displaced residents will not be left out in the cold. But it has not done enough, say a group of tenants who filed the latest in a series of
title: Tenants Sue Agency Over Brooklyn Project

body: 'ADVENTURES FROM EZRA JACK KEATS: APT. 3 AND MAGGIE AND THE PIRATE' (Tonight through Monday) Two books by this author and illustrator come to life onstage in the winter musical from Tada!, the youth theater troupe. ''Apt. 3'' focuses on the friendship that two children forge with a blind neighbor; ''Maggie and the Pirate'' is about, well, a girl
title: SPARE TIMES: Jan. 12 - Jan. 18; For Children

body: PRESS--Arthur, of New York and Florida, died on January 9, 2007. He was 77 years old. Mr. Press or Artie as he was known to those that knew him was born and raised in Brooklyn, NY. He attended Lafayette High School and Western Maryland College where he was selected as a first team All American in basketball and was subsequently selected by the
title: Paid Notice: Deaths PRESS, ARTHUR

body: The day after a disturbed man died after being shocked with a Taser stun gun in Queens by a police sergeant, a city police official yesterday provided a fuller account of the moments before the man apparently went into cardiac arrest. The man, Blondel Lassegue, 38, a former schoolteacher, struggled with the police on Sunday afternoon in a kitchen
title: Brooklyn Man, 38, Dies After Jolt From Police Taser

body: BROADWAY PLAYHOUSE (Sunday) Children will not only hear Rodgers and Hammerstein but also emulate them in this first concert in a series that examines great Broadway musicals. Young music lovers will join in interactive games and singalongs, see a mini version of ''The King and I'' and join the host, Sean Hartley, in writing a simple song. At 11
title: SPARE TIMES: Jan. 5 - Jan .11; For Children

body: SHERMAN--Arnold E. Beloved husband of Naomi S. Sherman. Loving father of William and Jane Sherman, Patty and Richard Rudolph, and Joseph and Lisa Sherman. Cherished grandfather of David, Michael, Jason, Vicky, Andrew, Sam and Nathan. Devoted brother of Florence Hartenstein and brother-in-law of Ruth Kotcher. Dear uncle, great-uncle and friend.
title: Paid Notice: Deaths SHERMAN, ARNOLD E

body: City, state and federal agencies granted final approvals last month to a half-dozen wide-ranging projects in a political aligning of the stars that will promote New York City's most ambitious economic development agenda in decades. Approval or financing was given to a Second Avenue subway; an extension of the Flushing Line to the Far West Side; a
title: Wave of Development, Cleared for Takeoff
